title: PDF Accessibility Checklist
subtitle: Step-by-step guide for creating PDF/UA compliant documents
intro: Creating accessible PDFs requires attention to structure, tags, and metadata. This checklist guides you through the process of ensuring your academic PDFs meet PDF/UA (ISO 14289-1) standards.

items.source: Start with a well-structured source document (Word, LaTeX, InDesign)
items.headings: Use proper heading styles (Heading 1, Heading 2, etc.)
items.alt: Add alt text to all images and figures
items.lists: Use built-in list formatting (not manual bullets)
items.toc: Include a table of contents with links
items.fonts: Use accessible fonts embedded in the document

latex.title: 2. LaTeX to PDF
latex.description: For LaTeX documents, use the accessibility package:

items.styles: Use built-in styles for headings and lists
items.alt: Add alt text: Right-click image → Edit Alt Text
items.reading: Check reading order in Accessibility Checker
items.export: Export: File → Export → Create PDF/XPS → Options → check 'Document structure tags'
items.verify: Verify with Adobe Acrobat Pro or PAC 2024

tagging.title: 4. PDF Tagging
tagging.description: Ensure your PDF has proper structural tags:

items.title: Title - Document title (not filename)
items.author: Author - Creator name
items.subject: Subject - Brief description
items.language: Language - Primary language code (e.g., en-US, ko-KR)

untagged.fix: Run 'Add Tags to Document' in Acrobat Pro

readingOrder.fix: Use Reading Order tool to reorder tags

missingAlt.fix: Right-click image tag → Properties → Add alt text

tableHeaders.fix: Tag cells as TH (header) instead of TD (data)

contrast.fix: Increase contrast or provide alternative format

fonts.fix: Re-export PDF with 'Embed all fonts' option
